results.title: Fire without smoke
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Dept of Scientific and Industrial Research
results.brief_description: Traces the development of a simple but effective device for abolishing the industrial smoke menace. In wartime the black smoke trails from ships’ funnels indicated the position of convoys. Experiments carried out on board ship and at the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research’s Fuel Resesarch Station resulted in a new boiler door fitment which minimised the danger. Redesigned to suit industrial boilers, the smoke eliminator door also saves a considerable quantity of fuel.

results.title: Fire weather
results.creator_credit: Media World and Victoria. Country Fire Authority
results.brief_description: This video looks at the effects of weather on bushfire behaviour. Weather factors discussed are temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric stability, air mass, pressure systems and fronts. Focusing mainly on Victoria, it concentrates on the implications for firefighters. Knowledge of these weather factors will enable the fire fighter to predict fire behaviour.

results.title: Fire safety
results.brief_description: A summary of some basic fire prevention methods aimed at school children. Advice is given on the best kind of matches to use, what to do in case of a gas leak, how to act in case of a fire - calling the fire department or sounding an alarm - how to treat minor burns etc. The advice is aided by little re-enactments involving children demonstrating the right methods.

results.title: Fire risks with underground conveyors
results.creator_credit: Grahame Tharp, Jack Chambers, Data Film Productions and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how fires are caused on mine conveyor belts, how correct pit maintenance can prevent many of these outbreaks and how National Coal Board research is developing devices and materials to reduce these risks. Reference is made in the film to the use of polyvinyl chloride plastic for conveyor belts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grahame Tharp, Jack Chambers, Data Film Productions and National Coal Board

results.title: Fire protection
results.brief_description: Starts with an old hand pump in action and horse-drawn fire tinder. Then shows various fire retardants - sprinklers, foam and Co2; firemen training - gas masks, resuscitation, safety curtains in cinemas, fire drill in schools.

results.title: Fire prevention in the home
results.brief_description: At a school assembly program during Fire Prevention Week the children are told how they can help prevent fires and each child is given a form to take to their parents to check their home for fire danger. One boy and his father go over their home observing electric outlets, danger spots in the basement and attic, care of matches and use of home-type fire extinguisher. Next day the children report what they have learned.

results.title: Fire on the rim
results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description: This series looks at the historical, cultural, social and geological aspects of the varying effects of natural disaster and calamity on the peoples of the Pacific Rim.

results.title: Fire mountain
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Dramatic close-up views of a volcano erupting and rare features associated with volcanic action. Filmed during the eruption of Kilauea, on the island of Hawaii in 1969, this was the second greatest eruption in Hawaii’s history, the fountain height exceeding 1800 feet. The lava cascade was more than twice the height of Niagara Falls.

results.title: Fire making
results.brief_description: What causes fire [fire making] in the forest, fields, laboratory, in primitive tribes: the Paris match of 1805; the Congreve match 1827; the Promethean match 1830; strike-anywhere match, plus the production of modern 1920s matches.

results.title: Fire into gold
results.creator_credit: Katie Jennings and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
The lands around the “ring of fire” have long attracted people by their beauty, natural riches and promise of great wealth, despite the perilious threat of natural disaster. In Bali, volcanoes have created fertile lands, whereas in Papua New Guinea, centuries of activity have resulted in a gold mountain, the richest mine in the world. In contrast, the movement of the earth’s plates have resulted in the geothermic pools and geysers in New Zealand, which have become popular tourist attractions, as have the famous volcanoes of Hawaii.
